q.a: it probably doesn't help that i've never seen this symbol before: , but essentially, what i discovered boils down to this, speaking in the key of C: the very nature of notes like D, F, G, and A, ... when all used together.... those all need to have certain relationships to each other simultaneously, which is actually impossible. the only way this 'secondary' chord seems to want to work is when it actually feels like all these relationships are true: the F and D have to have a good relationship, the F and A have to have a good relationship, the D and G have to have a good relationship, and the F and C, ... and the G and C, ...... and what i came to discover was that it's actually this subtlely impossible nature that gives this chord such a longing need to go back 'home' to the 1 chord. kind of blew my mind. i explained all of this as well as i ever possibly could, right here, and like i said, it gave me a deeper appreciation and validation for the 12 tone equal temperment system than i ever thought possible, and i have never questioned it since
q.q:
You responded to a question about tuning systems a while back. The asker wanted to know if you'd ever tried tuning completely in just intonation. You said it's a noble endeavor, but ultimately it's impossible; you couldn't even get a full major scale out of the harmonic series, much less a working system of chromatic harmony.

I've realized something which could go a long way towards solving this problem - I've even composed/arranged some nice music using this concept. (It is by no means my original idea, btw.)

Your problem was that you tried to create a major scale (C major, if I recall) in which each scale degree was only tuned one way, regardless of its 'function'. For example, F would always be the same pitch, whether it was the 3rd of a D minor chord or the 7th of a G7 chord.

The way I started thinking about just intonation tuning is this: all harmony diatonic to C major can be derived from the harmonic serie s of Bb (minus 4, because C, in this case, is defined as the 9th harmonic of Bb).

In the C overtone series, we can get a very nice version of the C major triad (1st, 3rd, and 5th harmonics), the G major triad (3rd, 9th, and 15th harmonics), the E minor triad (3rd, 5th, and 15th harmonics), and the B diminished triad (15th, 9th, and 21st harmonics).

In order to get the three remaining triads, you need to use some 'undertones' of C - notes for which C is an overtone. I thought about it like this - if we get C major and E minor triads from the C harmonic series - we can just transpose down a (harmonic) perfect fifth to get F major and A minor triads. Then we can transpose down another perfect fifth to get the D minor triad (3rd, 5th, and 15th harmonics of Bb).

Since F-2 and C are both overtones in the Bb-4 harmonic series, and since each overtone has a harmonic series of its own (which is still part of the original harmonic series), we can say that a ll harmo ny diatonic to C major can come from the Bb-4 overtone series and sound great.

However, to sound good, notes need to be tuned differently depending on what member they are in a chord. For example, the D minor triad in C sounds great on its own when tuned as the 3rd, 5th, and 15th harmonics of Bb-4. But the D minor triad can also be found within a G9 chord. In this case, a different tuning will be way more consonant - as the 3rd, 7th, and 9th harmonics of G+2 (which is the 3rd harmonic of C and the 27th harmonic of Bb-4). If I remember correctly, this is how you tried to tune a D minor triad a while back - it sounds consonant in the context of a G9 chord, but not in the normal context of a D minor chord.

I realize this is not so practical for live keyboard or fretted instruments, but it's been great for retuning recorded music or composing in a DAW.

q.q:
Okay, here's my situation.... I have been on a bonkers schedule for a little under a year, and in that time I have conquered a considerable chunk of the observable universe thanks to the schedule. It really drags you along and makes you get things done. But I'm thinking of going off the schedule, partially because I just rediscovered the unobservable universe and really wanna go crazy and do something different in there.

On one hand, this is exciting beyond the belief. Dropping the schedule feels like freedom. (I'm also pretty tired from making content daily, so I love the idea of a change of pace.) On the other hand, I haven't been off-schedule in a long time, and the schedule itself gave me the initial jolt of energy I needed to get going, so I fear the lack of direction/motivation that (sometimes) comes from having no schedule.

You've done all sorts of schedules and non-schedules... any advice?

q.a: right. but, .... i am working with the absolute fastest computer on the market for my operating system, and there is still significant wait time just to even see what i'm working on. working blind is something i've just decided i'm not willing to do anymore. Additionally, .... i drew up a fairly simple scene (1 image! not even a video) with some lights and reflections, .... i set the sample# to 1000. waited quite awhile, and after all 1000 samples ..... still an absurdly high quantity of noise. not even close to being noise free. and still significant wait time. for ONE frame. a video contains at least 30 frames per second (and i would strongly prefer 60). yes eevee is frustrating and wacko when it comes to reflections and transparencies, and i still need serious help with it, but when all the factors are considered for Cycles, it's just no after no after no after no. If there is a computer in existence that can do Cycles renders instantaneously, i will spend my entire life savings on it. but i am under the impression that it is not there. The good news is, when put into perspective, Eevee is absolute lightyears ahead of where i've been before

q.a: as long as i've heard a song more than 10 or 20 times, over the course of a few days, i automatically learn it and could not unlearn it. but the tricky part is if i have to learn (memorize) a song on short notice. for that, i absolutely just make a chart and then read it. i am pretty much bullet proof that way, in that case i would only have to hear a song once, i just write it down the first time. but in the rare case the director may say 'absolutely no reading' .... well ........ i'd be fucked. until the age of A.R. glasses
q.q:
Many years ago I had fun memorizing a couple hundred digits of pi. I used 5-digit groups for the first hundred, but after that I found it was better to use variable-length groups -- easier to make up a story around them, harder to mix up the order, and so on.

What's weird if I memorized them in my native language, which is not English, and it's really hard for me to recite the decimals in English. I have to pronounce them in my native language and translate the digits into English on the fly, which is hard to do at the same time. I memorized the sounds of the numbers, not the numbers themselves. I never decided to do that, it's just how I naturally did it. I wonder if other people memorized the shapes instead, and would have an easier time saying them in a different language by just visualizing the numbers instead of having to pronounce them internally.

I'm not a musician but I'm curious as to how you learn a song. Probably you don't ju st recall the specific notes or chords, but some higher-order pattern? Is this something you can explain in simple words?

q.a: keep writing songs, recording them, and figure out what's going to play on the screen while the song plays. if you think you can make a video, that's cool too. but if you can't, just designate something interesting to look at on the screen while your song is playing. and make a bunch of video files that have your song on it, with the visual. keep doing that, and make your own channel (even if it's just on your hard drive). keep a notebook, give updates, record commentary, ...... basically make your own tv show. and then after it has gone on for a few months or a year or so, whenver you are feeling ready, start looking around at various online platforms you like best, and make accounts there and start posting the content there. it's pretty much a steady staircase to success, if you start treating yourself like the star of your own show, immediately. i am just guessing at what you might be interested in, because you said "like you" (me), and pretty much what i do is i star in my own imaginary show, and then when i feel like the show is good enough i start posting it online. pretty cool

q.q: Bill, you talk about how in order to have absolute pitch, you need some reference point(s) that were instilled from a very young age. But what I do is I compare the note to a pre-selected list of songs, and I can tell the note's pitch by what song it matches. It's not always snap-instant, but I can usually get at least a half-step around the true note.

q.a: to put it to the test you should try to get it to work while another song is playing, and compare it to obtain that song's key. but i will tell you something ironic. you will hear the experts say "no, that doesn't count, that's just sonic memory. the real absolute pitchers can do it instantly." But for me, here's the twist: every single person i've ever met who claims to have absolute pitch, i test them on it and they fail miserably.... by way more than a half step

11.3.19 1:58 am

Wow! That's very encouraging.

I know letter chords like C, Am, Fmaj7, Gadd9, etc. And the Nashville number system; like 1 is the root, 2m, 3,4,5 6m, etc. and I understand tempo and keeping time and basic time signature.

q.a: nowadays with recordings so readily available, the importance of completely knowing notation is nothing of what it used to be. there used to be no records, so in order to even listen to music, you had to buy sheet music from the store and play it on the piano. but nowadays, even in a professional setting, if you're learning material, even if you CAN read full notation, it would be actually very irresponsible to not listen to a recording also, because no matter how good the notation is, there's still layers and layers of depth to the music that can never be accurately represented on paper. it depends what kind of work you are doing, but in almost every modern professional musical situation, if you know chord symbols, (and the relative number systems are a huge bonus also), and have good ears to go with it, that's an A grade professional package right there. with the possibly the specific exception of the world of classical orchestral music. Also it may be different if your main instrument is a lead instrument - in that case you might want to know how to read melodies. And in general, i would recommend learning rhythmic notation, because often you will see rhythmic figures written in charts, and also it will be a very valuable tool when talking about the material with other musicians, you can refer to different rhythmic figures. and it would also help to know the names of the notes
q.q:
